deck_excerpt: A fun casual deck utilizing the new support for Slifer. Get tribute fodder, summon Slifer, opponent cant summon anything with 0 or
deck_description: Purpose of the deck, get tribute fodder on the field and summon Slifer. Its a fun deck that isn't perfect (can brick a little sometimes). A lot of people on here could make it better and stronger by throwing in more meta cards like hand traps and such but this deck is designed for fun using God support cards, God themed typed cards or cards similar to the cards used in the anime by characters who summon the God cards (Reactor Slime/Egyptian God Slime for example).   The point of the deck is get tribute fodder (mostly tokens) on the board and get Slifer in your hand using spell cards or through the draw power and then lock your opponent out of summoning <2k monsters as your hand builds up and Slifer becomes a massive beat stick. Below is a quicks breakdown of the deck and why they are used: 1 x Obelisk: is thrown in because its only God that has built in protection and increase odds of you getting a God in your hand since just 3 Slifer isn't enough. Other monster's are pretty self explanatory. 3 x Reactor Slime: for its token effect and ability's to bring Metal Reflect Slimed on the field, which is then used for Egyptian God Slime. 3 x Ra's Disciple:Â gets another 2 and if you got a god and Advance Draw (combo this with The True Name), you'll get a God out on your turn or use Soul Crossing during your opponents turn, tribute their monster's and you then keep a few ready for another god to come out later. 3 x Scapeghost: is slow being a flip effect, but if it Flips, BOOM! 4 monsters....cant say no to that. 1 x Vanitys Ruler: because why not (can easily be taken out if don't like as the deck is at 41) Another tribute summon option with a good effect. Doesn't need to be here but fun if he is For the spell cards I've quickly explained above the combo of Card Advance and The True Name and the usage of Soul Crossing. 2 x Thunderforce Attack: Doesnt need to be at 3, easily a brick card early game but good enough to utilize for its destructive power on opponents turn, or its destructive and draw power if used on your turn. plus its a Slifer card so why not. 2 x Mound of Bound Creator + 1 x Terraforming: Extra protection for Slifer, plus using a Terraforming to get one to hand thins the deck (Can easily be taken and replaced if wish for hand traps or other cards you might prefer) 3 x Supply Squad: If you don't get a God, and your tokens are just a line of defense, this works quite nicely just to help get to Slifer or other cards. Especially fun when have 2 or all 3 copies out (if they don't get destroyed ofc) 1 x Scapegoat: Play during opponents turn, use them for link bait (hence the Link-1s and 2s in Extra Deck) 1 x Upstart Goblin: Thin deck The Monster Reborn, HFD and MST are there for the back row destruction and free special summon. These can easily be changed if you want for stronger/better/preferred cards, I use them cos I like them and when I paly casually with friends, back row is used quite a lot (plus HFD was in the Structure Deck, i enjoy the nostalgia) For Traps: 3 x Reckless Greed: used for more hand size and getting a Slifer in hand. Best played in conjunction with another copy of its self making it worth the loss of a draw phase for 2 turns. Combos nicely with Supply Squad as that allows you to draw as your tokens are maybe getting destroyed whilst you Reckless is stopping you drawing so you don't real feel the draw back as much. 2 x Metal Reflect Slime: in here for Reactor Slime effect and to get Egyptian God Slime out. Doesn't need to be at 3 cos Reactor Slime can get it from Graveyard and tbh could easily be a 1, but its a card I've always loved and I have 2 Ultimate rare copies so thought might as well use both. Can be reduced to 1 and throw in cards you'd like to use but its still a nice 3k DEF monster if used from hand. The Extra deck revolves around 2 x Egyptian God Slime: 3k beat stick, offer protection to other things and can be sued as 3 tributes for Gods. He is the sub-boss monster of the deck. Bring out using the Reactor and metal Reflect Slime combo mentioned previously Links: The link-1s and 2s are in here to be used in conjunction with Scapegoat and if they allow, for use with other tokens and monster's so your deck can possibly do something if all 3 Slifer's are hiding at the bottom of your deck. If you wanna use this build my links are probably not the best choice so they can all be changed for better cards or better choices, I'm just using the cards I have. Just ensure whatever link monster's you pick, tokens can be used to summon them and that you have enough Link1s/2s so you can have at least 3 link monster's on field to make full use of Scapegoat's effect.   Hope everyone has fun trying out my build, suggestions welcome. To be honest you could alter this build and make it Obelisk, just replace the Slifer specific cards with Obelisk and his specific cards. If your looking for a cheap build the money card in this is Egyptian God Slime its cocsltys roughly Â£20+ last I checked in UK (Not inc Black Luster but he's actually a proxy in my physical deck) so you can take him out and leave Reactor Slime and Metal Reflect in as their effects are still good and Metal Reflect has 3k DEF so not easy to power past.

deck_description: I'm not saying that all of these cards are good in a deck like this. This deck is more of a nostalgia deck for people who are looking to get back into the game casually and want to play newer versions of old cards. This deck goes first to end on "At Best" an Arcana Knight Joker, an Arcana Extra Joker, and 1 Thunderspeed Summon which will summon Sphere Mode. This is only if you draw literally the god hand going first as your end board is usually only 1 of those 3. First the poker knights: 1 Jack's Knight, 3 Queen's Knight, and 3 King's Knight. 3 Arcana Triumph Joker which is a horrible card going first while decent going second since she could've been a quick effect and nobody would've cared. She is a nice discard since you can summon her from grave using her own effect later on in the duel. 3 Joker's Knight who foolishes a poker knight to summon himself as a body with the same name. He can be used for Arcana Knight and Extra Joker. 3 Imperial Bower which is literally Rescue Rabbit. 3 Sphere Mode is the god I chose to maindeck since Thunderspeed doesn't have the Soul Exchange Effect that Soul Crossing has and it can search Sphere Mode on top of that since you can either choose to have 3 poker knights on field or use them for Arcana Knight/Extra Joker. 1 Fire Flint Lady for either an extender or fusion material for Gilti-Gearfried. 1 ROTA. 3 Fusion Deployment which is E Tele for any poker knight. 3 Unexpected Dai which unfortunately clashes with Imperial Bower, but you have no way of searching Bower so it's rarely a problem. Only 1 Face Card Fusion since your only fusions can only negate things that "TARGET" themselves. 3 Joker's Straight which is literally begging to be negated since it essentially gives you 3 bodies in the 3 poker knights. 3 Extrav. 3 Thunderspeed Summon. 3 Joker's Wild which copies one of your poker knight spells. Something to consider about the spell/trap lineup is that you can choose to run things like Pot of Avarice. All of the new support takes almost all copies of your poker knights out of the deck turn 1 so you have no follow-up if you draw something like Joker's Straight or Joker's Wild. You need some way to put your materials back into the deck to actually use your cards in later turns. Extra Deck is an Extrav build. 3 Arcana Knight Joker, 3 Black Luster Soldier - Soldier of Chaos, 3 Arcana Extra Joker, and 3 Link Spider. 3 Gilti-Gearfried the Magical Steel Knight. It is simply Arcana Knight Joker combined with Bad Aim that can also attack twice and has relatively generic fusion materials. Side Deck is just cards you can consider running. Obelisk cannot be targeted and with how easy it is to get monsters on the field in this deck, you can also tribute 2 monsters to Raigeki your opponent. Slifer is literally a floodgate that gets rid of normal summons and starting plays. Soul Crossing is insane if you open it and a god. Going second, consider breaking boards with Dark Ruler and spell/trap removal like Twin Twisters or something of that sort.

deck_description:
(Note this is a semi-competitive semi-casual Deck.) This Magnet Warrior Deck operates a lot like most present day Cyberse Decks, the only difference being that it is made up of Rock-types (because Rock-types need love too). The Deck offers mediocre swarming potential which allows it to easily crank out the Level 8 "Magna Warrior" monsters from the Main Deck and a lot of the offensive threats present in the Extra Deck. The Deck also has a lock down mode, where you'll want to have the following cards on the field (note that although this field IS achievable, it requires a couple turns of set-up):
  • Monsters: Knightmare Griphon (who must be linked to as many of your monsters as possible), Adamancipator Risen - Dragite, Gorgonic Guardian, and Berserkion the Electromagna Warrior.
  • Spells/Traps: Magnetic Field, and Triamid Pulse.
Knightmare Gryphon in the Main Monster Zone shuts down your opponent's Special Summoned monsters if they aren't linked, while protecting your own monsters, assuming it is linked to all of them. Adamancipator Risen - Dragite provides Spell/Trap negation as well as non-targeting and non-destroying removal of your opponent's cards. Gorgonic Guardian shuts down your opponent's monster effects and can eliminate defensive tokens (if you're into that). Berserkion the Electromagna Warrior adds extra coverage and is the only monster that can take advantage of Magnetic Field's secondary effects. Traimid Pulse let's you revive Adamancipator Risen - Dragite and Berserkion the Electromagna Warrior upon destruction (which works well with Magnetic Field), has the ability to recover Magnetic Field, and has the ability to destroy an opponent's card during their turn. Your opponent cannot do much in this situation with all of the limits brought forth, what more when the other capable monsters are brought forth?

It is made byÂ churningÂ fresh orÂ fermentedÂ creamÂ orÂ milkÂ to separate the butterfat from theÂ buttermilk. Butter consists ofÂ butterfat, milkÂ proteinsÂ and water.   Unsalted Butter This is your best bet for cooking and baking. For many recipes, it is recommended that you bring the butter to room temperature first so that it better incorporates with other ingredients. The exception is pie crust, for which cold butter is a must. If you wish, you can season unsalted butter yourself to meet your personal taste preferences when using it as a topping or spread.   Clarified Butter When butter is melted and made clear by separating and discarding the milk solids and water, it makes the perfect dipping sauce for shellfish and other seafood. But because it will not burn at high temperatures, it is also a good choice for frying and sautÃ©ing.   Cultured Butter Made from cultured cream, cultured butter has a rich, complex flavor. It is ideal for baking because the lower moisture content produces flakier pastries and fluffier cakes.   European-Style Butter This old-fashioned variation is made from cream that is churned more slowly and for a longer time. It has a butterfat content of at least 82 percentâhigher than standard butter. The increased amount of butterfat is beneficial for cooking and baking.   Whipped Butter After it is churned, nitrogen gas is whipped into butter to create this soft, spreadable butter.

deck_excerpt: 'Red-Eyes Slash Dragon'-deck with Lair of Darkness, Predaplant and Black Rose Dragon
deck_description: Monsters: Darkest Diabolos, Lord Of The Lair: it has a target-immunity against all card-effects and gets special summoned from the hand or the graveyard when a dark monster gets tributed. Ways to special summon it: -If you have The Black Stone of Legend you can use the effect to get a red-eyes-monster without losing a monster from the tribute. -If you tribute Linkuriboh to prevent battle damage it triggers the effect, if you use Linkuriboh's second tribute-effect from the graveyard on dark monsters it also works. -When you play Crossrose Dragon to summon Black Rose Dragon, it has also a tribute effect that triggers the effect. When you use Black Rose Dragon's effect to destroy all cards on the field when it's summoned you destroy also Darkest Diabolos, Lord Of The Lair, because you can only chain the summon effect after the trigger-effect of Black Rose Dragon. This means he will also get destroyed then, so you can still use it to get Darkest Diabolos, Lord Of The Lair but then you can't use Black Rose Dragon's effect. -Darkest Diabolos, Lord Of The Lair can also tribute dark monsters to put a card from the opponent's hand to the deck. -Advance Draw tributes a level-8-or-higher monster Albion the Blackclad Dragon: it has multiple different effects. -When you draw it you can shuffle it back into the deck, to draw a new card and bring Fallen Of Albaz to the Graveyard in the same time. This is good because then you can use Branded in White to fusion summon from the Graveyard or you can special summon Fallen Of Albaz to trigger the fusion-summon effect of it and use a 'level 8 or higher'-monster of the opponent as fusion-material. -When you have Albion the Blackclad Dragon in the hand or it is in the Graveyard, you can special summon it, but you have to discard Fallen of Albaz or Branded in White from the hand. -When Albion the Blackclad Dragon is in the Graveyard it can trigger the effect even when you do not have Fallen of Albaz or Branded in White in the hand, then you can shuffle it back into the deck and bring Fallen of Albaz or Branded in White to the graveyard. If you put Branded in White to the graveyard from the deck in this way you can set it to the field in the end phase. This works because it's name become Fallen Of Albaz when it's in the Graveyard or on the field, but not when it's in the hand, then you wouldn't get Branded in White in the end phase. Sage De Fleur: It has a special summon effect, that destroy's one of your monsters and one of the opponent cards, so you can shoot an important card with this effect, with Flawless Perfection Of The Tenyi and a normal monster or token you can choose it as a target and it won't get destroyed, because the monsters get destroyed after the special summon happened. When this card is sent from the field to the graveyard you get a level-1 plant monster from the deck to the hand, which is Predaplant Sarraceniant. It has to be on the field before it is sent to the graveyard, so you can not fusion summon it from the hand or discard it to trigger the effect, but you can fusion summon or link summon it from the field. It puts a monster from the graveyard back to the deck as the second effect then, and when you do not have a monster in the graveyard, the effect does not trigger and you won't get Predaplant Sarraceniant. With this second effect you can put fusion material for the red-eyes fusion back to the deck, so it can work even when one of the materials got destroyed first. You can for example also put Predaplant Chlamydosundew back to the deck to maybe fusion summon again with it later. You can let Sage De Fleur get destroyed if you have no other monsters and then special summon Predaplant Sarraceniant when the opponent attacks directly to destroy another monster and to get Predaplant Chlamydosundew for the next turn. Red-Eyes Black Dragon: To fusion summon Red-Eyes Slash Dragon with Red-Eyes Fusion you must have Red-Eyes Black Dragon and a Warrior-monster (Gearfried The Red-Eyes Iron Knight) in the deck or in the hand, or it won't work. You can also summon Red-Eyes Black Dragon with The Black Stone Of Legend or with Red-Eyes Baby Dragon and use it as a normal monster. This is good with Flawless Perfection Of The Tenyi, or if you cannot fusion summon it with Red-Eyes Fusion and you want to use Super Polymerization or Branded in White. Gearfried The Red-Eyes Iron Knight: The Red-Eyes Fusion target, it can shoot spells/traps with the 'Red-Eyes Baby Dragon'-combo. It can also special summon a Red-Eyes-Monster but then you can't use the shoot-effect. Red-Eyes Baby Dragon: When you use The Black Stone Of Legend it's best to summon Red-Eyes Baby Dragon with the tribute-effect. Then you can wait for an attack or attack an opponent monster, if you attack and it gets destroyed by battle you get Red-Eyes Black Dragon or Gearfried The Red-Eyes Iron Knight in the same battle-phase, so that you can attack again. With Red-Eyes Black Dragon you then have 2700atk and a normal monster, and with Gearfried The Red-Eyes Iron Knight you can unequip Red-Eyes Baby Dragon directly to shoot a spell/trap. If the opponent has a spell/trap this is the fastest way of shooting it without extra-costs, you get then a level-1-dragon to the hand, so it's also more effective then getting a 2700-monster. The best level-1 Dragon is Rokket Synchron because you can get a level-8 Synchro when you normal summon it with Red-Eyes Black Dragon in the graveyard, as an alternative you can also get The Black Stone Of Legend. To trigger this second effect of Red-Eyes Baby Dragon it has to get sent to the graveyard as an equipment (spell/trap), so if the monster gets destroyed you get nothing, because the equipment-target gets destroyed before the effect triggers. This is why you must unequip it with Gearfried The Red-Eyes Iron Knight's effect,Â  you can also trigger this effect with Red-Eyes Slash Dragon's effect which can destroy any equipment-cards for the negate-effect. Other alternatives are the shoot-effects of Sage De Fleur and Paleozoic Olenoides, that you could also use to shoot your own cards, or with the effect of Black Rose Dragon. Black Rose Dragon destroys the monster and the equipment at the same time, so the effect gets triggered by it. The Black Stone Of Legend: You can use it to summon Red-Eyes Baby Dragon, to have a better defense, or you can use it's tribute effect to trigger Darkest Diabolos, Lord Of The Lair's special summon effect. The second effect of it can bring Red-Eyes Black Dragon and Gearfried The Red-Eyes Iron Knight back in the deck if you want to fusion summon it with Red-Eyes Fusion. This effect can be used to get The Black Stone Of Legend back to the hand. You can not use the tribute effect in the same turn you got it back to the hand, but you can use it for Allure of Darkness, or to get Linkuriboh. Chaos Valkyria: It's a good special summon card. It can be used as a monster with a different type to link summon Crossrose Dragon. It's second effect can bring Darkest Diabolos, Lord Of The Lair or any other monster-card to the graveyard, but only when you play the second Chaos Valkyria in one duel to banish the first from the graveyard, you can not use the effect twice in one turn. Phantom Skyblaster: Good Token-card that works good with special-summons. The tokens are good with Flawless Perfection of the Tenyi, and you can also link-summon Predaplant Verte Anaconda, without other cards when you use Link Spider. Fallen Of Albaz: When it get normal summoned or special summoned you can discard one card and fusion summon a level 8 or higher monster of the opponent to Brigrand The Glory Dragon. You could also use an opponent's fusion-monster to summon Predaplant Dragostapelia, or 2 opponent dark monsters, when you have Lair of Darkness, to fusion summon Predaplant Triphyoverutum. You can put it with Albion the Blackclad Dragon from the deck to the graveyard, to special summon it later, if you draw Albion the Blackclad Dragon first. Branded in White is a Fusion-card that only works with at least one dragon as material, and that can be only used with cards in the graveyard when Fallen of Albaz (or Albion the Blackclad Dragon) is one of the materials. Another secondary effect is that you can Discard Branded in White with Fallen of Albaz's Trigger-effect if you have both in the hand, and then set it in the End-phase, this is powerful, because then you can fusion summon with Fallen of Albaz from the Graveyard in the next turn. If you summon Fallen of Albaz with Call of the Haunted or Escape From The Dark Dimension it also triggers the fusion-effect. Roxrose Dragon: When you normal summon it you get Blooming of the Darkest Rose as the only 'Rose'-card in the deck. When it is in the Graveyard and Black Rose Dragon gets destroyed by an opponent's card effect or by battle, you get it back to the hand. You can use it as a level-3 tuner with a level-4 monster and a level-1 monster to summon a level 8-synchro-monster. You can also summon Black Rose Dragon with only one other level-4 monster, but then you can not revive Black Rose Dragon with Crossrose Dragon's effect, after you used the destroy-effect. Predaplant Chlamydosundew: If you have a level-8-monster in the hand you can summon Greedy Venom Fusion Dragon with its fusion-effect, and then you also have a level-8 monster in the graveyard that you can banish when Greedy Venom Fusion Dragon gets destroyed to summon it again. You can also use it to fusion summon Predaplant Chimerafflesia, Predaplant Dragostapelia or Predaplant Triphyoverutum, and if you already have Predaplant Dragostapelia you can put predator tokens on the opponent monsters and then also use them as fusion material. Predaplant Sarraceniant: When it battles the opponent monster gets destroyed, so is good to set it as a defense, but you can also attack monsters to destroy them with the effect. When you have it in the hand you can special summon it when an opponent monster attacks directly, and you can get it to the hand with Sage De Fleur's effect. When it gets destroyed by battle or when it gets detroyed by your or your opponent's card effect you get Predaplant Chlamydosundew from the deck which you can use to fusion summon a Predaplant-monster. Rokket Synchron: It's a level-1 Tuner to summon Draco Berserker of The Tenyi with only one level-7 card. When you have it in the hand or maybe get it with Red-Eyes Baby Dragon's effect, you can normal summon it to summon Red-Eyes Black Dragon from the Graveyard and use it as Synchro-material. Spells: Allure Of Darkness, Flawless Perfection Of The Tenyi, Advance Draw, Chaos Space: Draw cards, Flawless Perfection Of The Tenyi is as a Field Spell also used to get more Tokens with Blooming Of The Darkest Rose, it can be used when you set monsters, when you summon tokens with Phantom Skyblaster, Blooming Of The Darkest Rose, Paleozoic Olenoides, Scapegoat and maybe Lair of Darkness. It also works with normal monsters and gives them a 'monster-effect'-immunity, you can use Red-Eyes Black Dragon or Berserker Of The Tenyi then. Flawless Perfection Of The Tenyi can be used to secure normal monsters and tokens from the destroy-effect of Black Rose Dragon, but it will also get destroyed after the monsters got protected by its effect. Advance Draw is a better alternative to Trade-In because you can summon level-8-or-higher-monsters very fast in the midgame, if you use the tribute effect it will also summon Darkest Diabolos, Lord Of The Lair, so you could tribute a fusion monster and still have a monster with 3000 atk then, it can tribute an opponent monster if you have Lair Of Darkness. Chaos space brings Chaos Valkyria to the hand, you also have to discard a dark monster, this way you can instantly special summon Chaos Valkyria by banishing a monster in the graveyard. For the draw effect you can banish Chaos Valkyria or any extra-deck monster (they cannot be normal summoned) with the second Chaos Valkyria. You could also banish Crossrose Dragon with it's own effect or a fusion/synchro monster with Greedy Venom Fusion Dragon's effect, it also works for Thousand-Eyes Restrict as the 'Instant Fusion'-target Lair Of Darkness: If you have Tribute Effects that tribute monsters you can also tribute the opponents monsters. You can use this effect with Darkest Diabolos, Lord Of The Lair on any monster, with Advance Draw and with Linkuriboh on level-1 monsters if it is in the graveyard. You could make a monster level-1 if you have Predaplant Dragostapelia with the Predator counters. You also get tokens with it together with the other tribute-effects that are self-tributes and with normal tribute-summons. The Second effect makes all monsters dark so you can fusion-summon the opponent's monsters with Super Polymerization or with Fallen Of Albaz. Scapegoat, Instant Fusion, Monster Reborn: Reborn-Effects, Special summon-effects, with Scapegoat summoned in the opponent's end phase, it's possible to summon Crossrose Dragon and Predaplant Verte Anaconda to clear the whole field with Black Rose Dragon and then normal summon after the destroy-effect, you can also use the tokens for defense or only for Predaplant Verte Anaconda. Red-Eyes Fusion, Super Polymerization, Branded in White: Fusion cards, you can 'copy' Red-Eyes Fusion and Super Polymerization with Predaplant Verte Anaconda. It's always best to first use Red-Eyes Fusion, to make the draw phase better and to not draw the fusion-material-cards later. You can get Branded in White with Albion the Blackclad Dragon if you discarded Albion the Blackclad Dragon first with another effect so that it is in the graveyard. Branded in White can fusion summon with material from the graveyard if you have Fallen of Albaz or Albion the Blackclad Dragon in the hand, on the field or also in the graveyard.   Traps: Call Of The Haunted, Escape From The Dark Dimension: Special Summon-Cards from the graveyard and the banished cards from Allure of Darkness or Chaos Valkyria. Paleozoic Olenoides, Blooming Of The Darkest Rose: good token-cards for Flawless Perfection Of The Tenyi, Blooming Of The Darkest Rose can be used more than one time because you can shuffle it back into the deck. With Blooming Of The Darkest Rose in the graveyard you have also a good protection for Predaplant Verte Anaconda, Predaplant Chimerafflesia, Predaplant Dragostapelia, Predaplant Triphyoverutum and Black Rose Dragon, if they would get destroyed by a card-effect, you can chain this card to it and banish them first until the next turn. You can also protect them from battle damage, especially Predaplant Verte Anaconda with 500 atk, if you use it before the battle. Storming Mirror Force: good defensive card that works good against other extra-deck monsters, it has a good earlygame-strength. This deck is best with The Black Stone Of Legendor Darkest Diabolos, Lord Of The Lair in the graveyard, then it becomes fast in the midgame. The deck is also a bit counterplay-heavy, so it can be good to wait a turn with some plays.   Extra Deck: Link: Linkuriboh, Link Spider: used to use the tokens,Â Linkuriboh has also two tribute-effects that trigger Darkest Diabolos, Lord Of The Lair's special summon effect, and that work good with Lair Of Darkness. You can also link-summon Linkuriboh when you have The Black Stone Of Legend. When you tribute it to prevent battle-damage, you can get The Black Stone Of Legend back to the hand and link-summon Linkuriboh again. Predaplant Verte Anaconda: It's best to alyways summon it first to get Red-Eyes Slash Dragon and to have Red-Eyes Black Dragon andÂ Gearfried The Red-Eyes Iron Knight in the graveyard and not in the deck for a better draw phase. Crossrose Dragon: You can summon Black Rose Dragon and destroy all cards on the field then with its effect. You can use it as a quick effect in your or in the opponent's turn. You need two monsters with differens types to summon it, and then you also need a plant monster that you can tribute for the effect. As plant monsters you can use Predaplant Chlamydosundew, Predaplant Sarraceniant, Predaplant Verte Anaconda or tokens from Blooming Of The Darkest Rose. You can also use the Fusion-predaplant-monsters because all cards get destroyed anyway. If you have 4 monsters a good play would be to summon Predaplant Verte Anaconda, and then use the effect to summon Predaplant Chimerafflesia by using it and one of the opponent monsters as material. Then you can't special summon, but you can activate the Crossrose-effect in the opponent turn and use the Predaplant Chimerafflesia as the tribute, this way you get Red-Eyes Fusion to the hand in the next turn because of the secondary effect of Predaplant Chimerafflesia. Berserker Of The Tenyi: It's a normal monster if you have Flawless Perfection Of The Tenyi. Synchro: Black Rose Dragon: It's effect can destroy all cards on the field, which is good to outplay a lot of combo's that need 2 or 3 cards to work. When you summoned it with Crossrose Dragon you also get it back after all cards got destroyed but it only has 2400 atk. You don't have to use the destroy effect but then you can not use it later, if you have it on the field with or without the destroy-effect you can also turn monsters from defense position to attack position and change the atk to 0, by banishing a plant-monsters from the graveyard. Ruddy Rose Dragon as a level-10-synchro-monster is also not a good card in a graveyard deck because it only destroys all cards when you banish the graveyard-monsters. Cyberse Quantum Dragon: The level-7-alternative to Black Rose Dragon if you have Roxrose Dragon and a level-4-monster. Cyberse Quantum Dragon can put extra-deck monsters back into the extra-deck by attacking them, so they won't get targeted, with a link monster you can also build a 'wall' with it. Draco Berserker Of The Tenyi: It's a strong Level-8 Snychro-monster that you can summon very fast when you play Rokket Synchron to get Red-Eyes Black Dragon from the Graveyard. 'Level 8'-monsters are goot for Greedy Venom Fusion Dragon, then he can come back one time for every level 8 monster in the Graveyard, you can also use it as fusion-material. This card is an alternative to Borreload Savage Dragon, Borreload Savage Dragon is slower in the early-game and in the deck are only a few link-monsters, it is a dragon and also stronger as a 'midgame-card', but this deck needs fast combo's for the early-game because most combo's need 1 or 2 turns to function. You can also revive Draco Berserker Of The Tenyi and it still works, but you can not revive Borreload Savage Dragon and use its effect. Draco Berserker Of The Tenyi's negate works only for monster-effects but it has a banish effect and a double-attack-effect. Fusion: Thousand-Eyes Restrict: 'Instant Fusion'-target Brigrand The Glory Dragon: It is a 'Fallen of Albaz'-Fusion to use the fusion-effect of Fallen Of Albaz with an opponent monster. It has to be level 8 or higher as an alternative to Sprind The Irondash Dragon and Titaniklad The Ash Dragon. It also has the best effects together with the other monster, because it has 'battle-damage'-immunity and can protect other monsters from the opponent targeting monster-effects. Red-Eyes Slash Dragon: It is a bit like Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon but a bit weaker. You have to summon it as the first 'boss-monster' if possible in every duel, to have a better draw phase. This makes the duels similar to each other, and it's often about the flow how you archieve the set goals of the deck. It can negate one card or monster effect per turn, but only if you already attacked the opponent. When you attack you get the equipment that you can destroy to trigger the effect, the only way to get a second negate in one turn is to destroy Red-Eyes Baby Dragon while it is equipped to Red-Eyes Black Dragon because in the deck are no other Equip-spells and also no other warriors, and it would also take too long to use them, Gearfried The Red-Eyes Iron Knight could have an equip but it is already used as the 'equipment'-warrior. You still can attack with two Red-Eyes-monsters, this way, if you negate one time during the battle, you then maybe get the negate-effect back when you attack with the second Red-Eyes-monster. It is not good to play Red-Eyes Slash Dragon in the first turn, because you only have 2800 atk then instead of 3000 and also no negate, so you have to wait until you can attack after you summoned it or you revive it to attack then. Then it can be strong, because it can negate every turn after it attacked without further activation costs but attacking. Predaplant Chimerafflesia: it's a good starting-monster in the early-game, because you have 3500atk in a battle and the opponent loses 1000 atk, so the opponent has to destroy it with card-effects. You also get Red-Eyes Fusion or maybe Super Polymerization to the hand in the next turn after it got destroyed. Predaplant Dragostapelia: it can negate monster effects by putting predator-counters on them as a quick-effect that works once per turn. Predaplant Triphyoverutum: It can be often summoned with Super Polymerization and Lair of Darkness with up to 3 of the opponent's monsters. It has a special-summon negate as effect, and if you fusion summon it then with one dark monster to Predaplant Dragostapelia you can put one predator counter on a monster and directly special summon Predaplant Triphyoverutum again from the graveyard. Greedy Venom Fusion Dragon: It is the strongest Predaplant-monster as a 'midgame'-monster. Every time it gets destroyed all monsters on the field gets destroyed, then you can get it back by banishing on of the level-8 monsters from the graveyard. Since it needs a level-8 monster as material you always have at least one in the graveyard, except you used one of the opponent monster as material. It also has a negate-effect.

deck_excerpt: A Familiar-Possessed deck that also runs Lyna and Dharc.
deck_description:
"The power of the elements are fickle and disastrous, therefore it takes a very skilled mage to control these elements, lest they be controlled by them. The Charmers are a group of students with the potential to become such mages. They train under with the great Doriado, a dryad that not only mastered one element, but six. They train so that they can become masters of their element Originally there were four, Eria, Wynn, Hiita and Aussa. these maidens were discovered when their respective families noticed them in a trance and acting strangely. Their trance was a result of possession by a being aspected to the same element. Doriado managed to find such beings and quell their hold before taking the girls who then adopted their possessors as familiars. The bond between the students and their familiars, as well as each other, strengthened over the years. Lyna and Dharc came later. A pair of siblings tuned to the primordial and chaotic elements of light and shadow. Doriado noticed they seemed to have greater control over their powers and even contact with their possessors before meeting her, and that their previous circumstances weren't as king to them as their peers'. The fates of these six are now as avatars of the elements. Forces of nature and elementals themselves. Will these roles lead to them being consumed by that they study to tame or will their humanity shine through and make them powerful mages in their own right? And what will become of the familiars as their training is compete?" What we have here is a Familiar-Possessed Charmer Control deck. As such it relies mainly on two cards. Fairy Tail - Luna and Awakening of the Possessed - Nefariouser Archfiend for consistency and power. While most people likely use the original quartet of Aussa, Hiita, Eria and Wynn and some had decided to add in Lyna as well since LIOV, I make the decision to run all 6 of the FP cards and all the available Link counterparts, as well as all 4 of the Awakened Familiars (thought they are all at one each) The gist of their game plan seems to be to use Awakening of the Possessed to turn your Charmers into beatsticks, but also to go for a control playstyle with Luna. To the latter end I use the in-theme cards Possessed Partnerships and Grand Spiritual Art - Ichirin. For off-theme cards I run Secret Village of the Spellcasters, Witchcrafter Golemn Aruru, Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring and Ghost Reaper & Winter Cherries. the Side deck also plays into this with Dark Ruler No More, Effect Veiler, Twin Twisters and Denko Sekka in triplicate as well as a 3rd Possessed Partnership and for one-offs Raigeki and Dimensional Barrier. I also run two copes of Fairy Tail Tales, but for some reason that's not in the database (Rohcha however is, but I'm obviously not running her). Spirit Charmers, Spellbook of Knowledge, Terraforming and Metaverse are there to help me get to key cards.   Rounding out the extra deck would be...
  • Cherries Targets: Winda, Trishula and Vortex (might replace Trish with The Arrival Cyverse, Dark Templar or Dark Infant)
  • Rank 4s: Castel, Emeral, Dweller and Tornado Dragon (Some can double as Cherries targets, thought I might replace Dweller for another Cherries target)
  • Links: Apollousa, Borrelsword, Barricadeborg Blocker (Link-4s can also double as Cherries targets)
I'm certain there is room for improvement, especially regarding the ED (and the lack of Trap Trick), so any and all feedback is appreciated.

Oh boy it's banlist season. Dino got hit, Dragons finally got hit and Drytron's allowed to live for once. While these changes were to be expected Konami went a little wilder than last time. There's the Drident ban. A *checks notes* quick effect, targeted destruction for *checks notes again* face-up cards? I'm sure that'll stop Zeus. It does stop Utopic Future Dragon from selling but it's not like that card releases next set in 2 weeks or anything, right? Right? Then there's Engage back to 1, making Sky Striker meta again. Well, every eight match at least. And how does Konami justify bringing back such a powerhouse? By giving us Salamangreat players a...chokepoint? Don't get me wrong, bouncing a monster's fun and all and summoning Jack from your deck to add Gazelle back to hand is great but it's not like it increases the deck's power level like Engage does. It did, however, invite a lot of people to brainstorm on how to best play Salamangreat. And the results are...mellow. What do I mean by that? Let's break down the issues modern Salamangreat deckbuilding has.   The Flame Bufferlo versus Lady Debug debate: Salamangreat has two main starters, Bufferlo and Debug. Both are fantastic cards but each for completely different reasons. Let's go over their core strenghts. I'm a fan of Bufferlo so I'll start with that one. Flame Bufferlo: While it is a level 3 Fire Effect monsters let me be clear: There's an almost 0 percent chance you'll use it to make Miragestallio! It's strength is that it's effect doesn't trigger until it's linked off, meaning you can "chainblock" it's effect with Balelynx, guaranteeing you a draw 2 effect. It discards when resolving it's effect, making way for another great strength of his. It doesn't contest with your Salamangreat monsters for your Normal Summon. Jack Jaguar, Falco and especially Foxy are other cards that you could normal summon to start your combo. You can discard them with Cynet Mining but it's far more likely that you'll get them into the GY by linking them off. If you normal summon Bufferlo instead he then discards them, turning your otherwise normal summon into an extender. In short, he doesn't "add" to your normal summon since he'll just turn your other normals into specials. What he doesn't do is search Gazelle. That makes him fairly weak in a deck that runs only one of each trap and a lot of handtraps. If you're going first seeing handtraps is great and all but traps are generally stronger and if you're going second drawing into your handtraps then is usually too late. but if you're heavy on traps, and on 2 of each Salamangreat trap, it doesn't matter as much if you go first or second, you'll draw, set, pass and win the game during your opponents turn. After all, Gazelle only sets up one interruption anyways and good luck resolving that against an established board. Since it "converts" your Salamangreat normal summons I'd recommend 3 Foxy and 2 Spinny (Foxy is great at playing through Nibiru as you don't need to control a Salamangreat monster). Lady Debug: This card is a powerhouse. It's a one card OTK with Accesscode Talker and searches Gazelle or a Spinny if you already have access to Gazelle. But the strength of a card's usually negatively correlating to how often you'll resolve it. It's an easy choke and loses to both negates and spot removal. That's why it's generally used in a deck playing a more handtrap/extender oriented version (I say extender oriented but I don't think there's much of a difference in how many extenders both versions play unless you're leaning strongly towards level 3 spam). If it resolves you might just as well win and if you don't you just try again next turn and stop your opponent with your handtraps. Another strong suit of Debug is that it searches Prohibit Snake which, in this Winda infested format, is one of Salamangreat's only outs to that card. Since it does use up your normal summon I'd recommend 2 Foxy and 3 Spinny. The Mix: This is where I find my issues with late Salamangreat deckbuilding. A lot of people like running Bufferlo and Debug in a 3-2 or 2-3 ratio, which I personally don't think is a good idea. As a normal summon they conflict with each other, bricking if you draw both. It also results in people playing both handtraps and traps but both only to a smaller amount, making both strategies less impactful. Now Bufferlo might just draw handtraps going second and your Debug is less likely to resolve as you have less of a chance to disrupt your opponent on their turn. I saw some people run both at three to which I gotta say: Why? In short, I think both version's have their own individual strenghts and weaknesses and I'd advise not to play a mix of both. You'll just end up playing into both weaknesses without gaining much of their individual strengths, resulting in, as I said earlier, mellow decks.   The Bufferlo Version: I said I before and I'll say it again, I love Flame Bufferlo. Drawing 2 and worst case setting a few feels great. Not having to worry about having your normal summon negated is awesome. Seeing your opponent's reaction in realtime when they learn that Bufferlo triggers in hand if they bounce it is priceless. Also I played Drytron when it was meta with VW and everyone was siding against it. No need to say, I did not often resolve my cards and started leaning towards control in the process. Anyways I don't think there's one right version of this deck. Some might play Parallel eXceed, some might not. Some might play less Spells and add Imperial Order to their list. Linguriboh's also totally optional and just a card I personally like a lot. Heatleo is just as good at two but I needeed space for Linguriboh and I mostly summon one to force out backrow anyway. So this is not so much me asserting Bufferlo's dominance or claiming toÂ  have figured out the perfect deck but rather an introduction into the diversity of Salamangreat. The same is true for the side deck. There are a lot of good cards to side and I personally feel like it's hard to settle on which cards are best, especially now that the format is so young (so young in fact that hasn't even started). Nibiru, Lancea and Droll are all incredible blowout cards when you know you're going second, while floodgates might just win you the match going first but Rivalry and Gozen's strength is directly related to the current meta. Some backrow removal is important too and other's - and maybe I myself later down the line - might lean a little deaper into backrow removal. Reboot's great though, pretty much instantly wins you the game against control but too situational to play in Main. If there's anything I strongly stand by in this deck profile it's that I don't think the Bufferlo-Debug-Handtrap-Trap mix I see a lot of lately is the way to go and that purer version's of each will be the way to go. Also don't get me wrong, Miragestallio's great and I'm happy to have it back!

deck_excerpt: Go-first Shark Deck that does OK going second!
deck_description:
This here is my attempt at a Shark deck, using Number 4: Stealth Kragen and Gozen Match to hopefully lock down the opponent's summons. Actually, even if you don't end on those two, going first is your best option.

If going first, you can sit on a Number 59: Crooked Cook that was summoned with Right-Hand Shark, leaving you with a Rank 4 that can't be destroyed by battle, and is unaffected by everything if it's the only card on your field. OR you can set up boards of Toadally Awesome, Torrential Tribute, and even Utopic Future Dragon.

But if you need to go second, you have Utopia Double for OTKs and 2 Cosmic Cyclone and Harpies' Feather Duster because screw backrow.

 

As for this card's name, it's named after "The Great Wave off Kanagawa", one of Japan's most popular paintings and works of art.
